column5: EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)  INDICATION:  History: ___ with cough// Pneumonia  TECHNIQUE:  Single AP upright portable view of the chest  COMPARISON:  ___  FINDINGS:   Right-sided Port-A-Cath terminates in the low SVC/cavoatrial junction, without evidence of pneumothorax. column5: INDICATION:  ___ female with Gram-negative rod sepsis.  COMPARISON:  ___.  TECHNIQUE:  Single frontal chest radiograph was obtained portably with the patient in an upright position.  FINDINGS:  2.3 cm left lower lobe pulmonary nodule is better evaluated by CT.  There is mild increased pulmonary vascular engorgement with cephalization, increased heart size, and increased mediastinal venous engorgement, suggestive of congestive heart failure.  Asymmetric density of the right lower lobe compared to the left may represent asymmetric edema, less likely infection.  No pleural effusion or pneumothorax is seen.  Aortic calcification is seen.  An enteric catheter courses below the diaphragm with tip in the left upper quadrant.  IMPRESSION:   1. Interval development of mild congestive heart failure.  2. Asymmetric density of the right lower lung compared to the left, likely edema, less likely infection.

column5: EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PA AND LAT)  INDICATION:  ___ year old woman with hx locally advanced pancreatic ca with a week long hx of Right rib pain when taking a deep breath  // rule out rib fracture/metastatic disease  TECHNIQUE:  Chest PA and lateral  COMPARISON:  PET-CT ___.  ___ chest radiograph.  FINDINGS:   Small to moderate bilateral pleural effusions are new compared to the prior PET-CT of ___ and associated with adjacent bibasilar atelectasis.  Cardiomediastinal contours are within normal limits.  Within the lungs, a right middle lobe on 1 cm nodular opacity adjacent to the minor fissure has apparently grown since the prior CT PET study and is new compared to an older chest radiograph of ___.   Several additional small pulmonary nodules are also evident and not well characterized radiographically.  A lobulated opacity in the retrosternal region could either be mediastinal or parenchymal in location.  Mild compression deformities in the upper thoracic spine are new compared to ___.  IMPRESSION:   New bilateral pleural effusions.  Enlarging right middle lobe nodule and apparently new lobulated retrosternal opacity, concerning for metastatic disease.  RECOMMENDATION(S):  Chest CT may be considered for more complete evaluation of these findings.  NOTIFICATION:   The findings were discussed with ___, M.D. by ___, M.D. on the telephone on ___ at 11:05 AM, 5 minutes after discovery of the findings.

column5: INDICATION:  Preoperative evaluation of patient with FDG-avid right pulmonary and hilar nodules.  COMPARISON:  Chest radiograph from ___ as well as FDG tumor imaging PET-CT from ___.  FINDINGS:  A combination of emphysematous and fibrotic changes are visualized diffusely throughout bilateral lungs along with more focal basilar reticular opacities in the lower and mid lungs.  An area of increased opacity is visualized in the periphery of the right upper lobe, partially obscured by the overlying right scapula.   Post-surgical changes are visualized with mediastinal clips, a ventriculoperitoneal shunt, and median sternotomy wires; the two most inferior of which appear fractured.  There is no focal consolidation, effusion, or pneumothorax.  IMPRESSION: 1.  Peripheral right upper lobe opacity corresponds to known pulmonary nodules more fully characterized on recent CT and PET-CT studies. 2.  A combination of upper lung predominant emphysema and basilar predominant fibrosis is visualized throughout both lungs.

column5: EXAMINATION: Chest:  Frontal and lateral views  INDICATION:  History: ___ with chest pain *** WARNING *** Multiple patients with same last name!// assess for pna ptx  TECHNIQUE:  Chest:  Frontal and Lateral  COMPARISON:  None.  FINDINGS:   The lungs are hyperinflated.  Subtle relatively nodular opacities projecting over the right lung apex could be due to pleural thickening, but are not optimally assessed on this study.  There is also an equivocal nodular opacity projecting over the anterior left sixth rib.  No focal consolidation seen elsewhere.  No pleural effusion or pneumothorax is seen.  Cardiac silhouette is mildly to moderately enlarged.  The aorta is tortuous.  No pulmonary edema is seen.  IMPRESSION:   Hyperinflated lungs.  Subtle nodular opacity projecting over the right lung apex could be due to pleural thickening but pulmonary nodules are not excluded and findings are not optimally assessed on this study.  In addition, equivocal nodular opacity projecting over the anterior left sixth rib.  Recommend outpatient chest CT for further evaluation.  No evidence of pneumothorax.  Mild to moderate cardiomegaly.

column5: HISTORY:  Fever of unknown etiology.  TECHNIQUE:  Upright AP and lateral views of the chest.  COMPARISON:  CT torso ___ and chest radiograph ___.  FINDINGS:  The heart size is normal.  The mediastinal and hilar contours are unchanged, with mild calcification of the aortic knob.  Hilar contours are stable.  Pulmonary vascularity is not engorged.  Innumerable pulmonary nodules are seen in both lungs compatible with metastatic disease.  Small right pleural effusion appears increased in size compared to the prior exam.  There is associated right basilar opacity which may reflect compressive atelectasis.  Streaky left basilar opacity also may reflect atelectasis.  There is no pneumothorax.  Mild degenerative changes are seen in the thoracic spine.  A lytic lucency within the left proximal humerus measuring 9 mm is not fully assessed on this study.  IMPRESSION:  1. Increased size of small right pleural effusion.  Bibasilar airspace opacities may reflect atelectasis though infection cannot be excluded.  2. Bilateral pulmonary metastases, relatively unchanged compared to the prior exam.  3. 9 mm lytic lesion in the left humeral head, incompletely assessed, but concerning for metastasis.

column5: INDICATION:  Cough, fever.  FINDINGS:  Two views of the chest are reviewed without comparison.  There are multiple small 6 mm round nodular densities in the right lower lung adjacent a a 9 mm probable dilated bronchus-on-end with peribronchial cuffing.  The mediastinal contours are remarkable for bilateral hilar fullness that may be secondary to adenopathy. The pulmonary vasculature and osseous structures are unremarkable.  IMPRESSION: 1.  Dilated bronchus-on-end in the right lower lung adjacent multiple small (6 mm) nodular densities that may present combination of micronodules and dilated mucus-impaced bronchioles secondary to acute or chronic infection (with differential also including tuberculosis).  Neoplastic pulmonary nodules cannot be excluded. 2.  Probable hilar adenopathy.  COMMENT:  Chest CT is recommended for further clarification.  Recommendation posted to the ED dashboard at the time of the study.

column5: EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PORTABLE AP)  INDICATION:  ___ year old man with NSTEMI, COPD, found down in street// eval for fracture, pna  COMPARISON:  None.  FINDINGS:   There is background hyperinflation, suggesting background COPD.  There is probable mild cardiomegaly.  Aorta is minimally unfolded.  Mild prominence of the hila with a tapered appearance could reflect pulmonary hypertension.  There is possible minimal upper zone redistribution, but no evidence of CHF.  No focal infiltrate or effusion is identified.  There is a curvilinear lucency projecting over the right upper lung between the right posterior fourth and fifth ribs.  Although this raises the possibility of a right upper pneumothorax, vessels are seen projecting beyond it and this more likely represents artifact due to skin fold.  There is no associated atelectasis.  Rounded lucency projecting between the anterior fourth and fifth ribs most likely reflects rib synostosis.  A finding in the lateral right mid lung is considered less likely.  Abutting the lower left chest wall, overlying the left anterior seventh rib, there is a 3.8 mm nodular opacity, possibly a small pulmonary nodule.  IMPRESSION:   Suspect background COPD, with possible pulmonary hypertension.  Mild cardiomegaly.  No CHF, focal infiltrate or effusion is detected.  Curvilinear lucency at right lung apex more likely represents a skin fold than a pneumothorax.  Clinical correlation is requested.  If there is clinical concern for pneumothorax, a repeat film, obtained at end expiration of the respiratory cycle could help for further assessment.  Probable normal variant or old posttraumatic synostosis of the right fourth and fifth anterior ribs.  Please see comment above.  No displaced rib fractures identified on these lung technique films, to suggest acute rib injury.  3.8 mm nodule abutting the lower left chest wall.  Further assessment with nonemergent chest CT is recommended.  RECOMMENDATION(S):  If clinical concern for right pneumothorax, than repeat AP chest x-ray with low inspiratory volume.  Recommend nonurgent chest CT for further assessment of a 3.8 mm nodule abutting the lower left chest wall.

column5: CHEST RADIOGRAPH   HISTORY:  Dyspnea on exertion.  COMPARISONS:  ___.  TECHNIQUE:  Chest, PA and lateral.    FINDINGS:  The patient is status post replacement of the aortic valve.  The heart is mildly enlarged.  The mediastinal and hilar contours appear unchanged including mild unfolding of the thoracic aorta.  There is increasing right lateral and particularly posterior pleural thickening along the right lower hemithorax suggestive of a loculated pleural effusion.  Pleural thickening in the left costophrenic sulcus is similar.  Patchy new opacities in the lower lungs, particularly in the right lower lobe, are concerning for pneumonia.  Potentially a relatively dense focus along the inferior aspect of the right hilum on the frontal view may represent a pulmonary nodule.  There is also a rounded opacity projecting over the left lower lung, possibly a nipple shadow versus pulmonary nodule.  IMPRESSION:  1.  Patchy opacities, particularly in the right lower lobe, suggesting pneumonia in the appropriate clinical setting.    2.  Increased pleural thickening in the right lower hemithorax suggesting a loculated effusion.    3.  Possible pulmonary nodules.    If pneumonia is suspected clinically as the etiology for new opacities, then radiographs are recommended following resolution in approximately eight weeks. Otherwise, chest CT is recommended to evaluate further.  An entry was placed into the Radiology Department critical results dashboard for communication to the referring physician ___ ___.

column5: EXAM:  Chest, single AP upright portable view.  CLINICAL INFORMATION:  ___ female with history of Wegener's granulomatosis.  ___.  Reference also made to prior chest CT from ___.  FINDINGS:  Single AP upright portable view of the chest was obtained.  Left-sided PICC now terminates at the very proximal SVC/SVC-brachiocephalic junction and has migrated proximally since the prior study.  The lungs remain hyperinflated with flattening of the diaphragm, suggesting chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.  There is a wedge-shaped opacity in the lateral left lung base and medial left lung base/retrocardiac, maybe due to atelectasis although underlying consolidation cannot be excluded.  Multiple known pulmonary nodules and right middle lobe collapse are chronic and better evaluated with CT.  No pleural effusion or pneumothorax is seen.  There is minimal biapical pleural thickening.  The cardiac and mediastinal silhouettes are stable and unremarkable.  Degenerative changes are noted at the right acromioclavicular joint.  Multiple old right-sided rib fractures are seen, as also seen on prior chest CT.  IMPRESSION: 1.  Left-sided PICC has migrated more proximally as compared to the prior study, now terminating in the proximal SVC/SVC-brachiocephalic junction. 2.  Lateral and medial left base opacities, as above, may relate to atelectasis although underlying consolidation is not excluded.

column5: AP PORTABLE CHEST, ___ AT 1529 HOURS  HISTORY:  Brain mass.  COMPARISON:  Chest x-rays from outside hospital earlier same day.  FINDINGS:  There are scattered ill-defined mass lesions throughout the right lung, the largest is approximately 2.5 cm in diameter situated over the posterior right seventh rib.  Additionally, there is a large lobulated convexity in the aorticopulmonary window suspicious for mass lesion and/or adenopathy.  A reticular interstitial pattern is noted throughout.  There is hyperexpansion suggestive of underlying obstructive lung disease.  The cardiac silhouette is within normal limits for size.  No effusion or pneumothorax is noted.  The osseous structures are otherwise unremarkable.  IMPRESSION:  Mass lesion on the right suprahilar lung and likely in the aorticopulmonary window on the left.  Other smaller densities project over the lateral aspects of the lower right ribs which may be pulmonary nodules versus callus from healed rib fractures.  Underlying obstructive lung disease.

TARGETED REVIEW OF CHEST CT FROM ___  FINDINGS:   Again seen is diffuse bilateral airspace disease, there assessed on the dedicated chest CT obtained less than an hour previous.  The radiographic appearance is overall similar a subtle there is of increased opacity at the right base appear to be present.  No gross effusion identified.   The endotracheal tube terminates 2.4 cm above the level of the carina.  A right internal jugular central venous line overlies the upper right atrium.  No pneumothorax is detected.   IMPRESSION:   Diffuse bilateral airspace disease, similar to earlier the same day, though some interval increase in the opacity at the right base laterally appears to be present.  As suggested on the recently obtained chest CT, this appears to represent an combination of background pulmonary nodules with new superimposed parenchymal opacities, raising the question of multifocal pneumonia or diffuse aspiration.  In the appropriate clinical setting, hemorrhage might also account for this appearance.  The CT also suggested an element of pulmonary edema.  Lines and tubes as described.  The right IJ central line tip overlies the upper right atrium.  If clinically indicated, this could be retracted by approximately 1.5 cm.  No pneumothorax detected.

column5: CHEST RADIOGRAPH  INDICATION:  Chest pain, concern for bulging mediastinum, evaluation for interval change.  COMPARISON:  ___.  FINDINGS:  On today's radiograph, the appearance of the mediastinum is normal. There is a suggestion of pulmonary emphysema in both upper lobes.  In addition, better visible than on the previous examination, a linear opacity at the bases of the right upper lobe that is better visible on the frontal than on the lateral film.  This structure could represent a small pulmonary nodule with adjacent parenchymal reaction or a localized atelectasis.  Given that the lesion was not visible on the previous examination two days ago, atelectasis is the most likely possibility.  To confirm, a repeat chest radiograph should be performed within four weeks from now.  Minimal blunting of the costophrenic sinuses on the lateral image, probably caused by lesser inspiration than on the previous examination and a small degree of pleural fat.  No evidence of pneumonia or pulmonary edema.  Unchanged normal size of the cardiac silhouette.

This structure could represent a small pulmonary nodule with adjacent parenchymal reaction or a localized atelectasis.  Given that the lesion was not visible on the previous examination two days ago, atelectasis is the most likely possibility.  To confirm, a repeat chest radiograph should be performed within four weeks from now.  Minimal blunting of the costophrenic sinuses on the lateral image, probably caused by lesser inspiration than on the previous examination and a small degree of pleural fat.  No evidence of pneumonia or pulmonary edema.  Unchanged normal size of the cardiac silhouette.
column7: This structure could represent a small pulmonary nodule with adjacent parenchymal reaction or a localized atelectasis.

column5: EXAMINATION:  CHEST (PA AND LAT)  INDICATION:  History: ___ with h/o metastatic breast CA with R upper back pain // acute process?  COMPARISON:  Chest x-ray dated ___. The cardiomediastinal silhouette is probably unchanged, allowing for positioning and technical differences. No CHF or appreciable effusion.  There are extensive changes in the left upper zone that are in keeping with findings on the ___ CT scan, with focal left upper zone opacity, some retraction superiorly,  and slight tenting of the left hemidiaphragm. This apparently corresponds to a previous radiofrequency ablation site, with chronic fibrotic changes.  A single clip is noted nearby.  On the right, there is focal opacity at the right lung apex, extending medially to the right paratracheal soft tissue. This is similar to the scout film from the ___ CT scan and likely corresponds to the right upper posterior mediastinal mass identified on that CT scan.  There may be minimal atelectasis at both bases. However, otherwise, no focal opacity to suggest acute pneumonic infiltrate or site of aspiration is identified. No pneumothorax is detected.  Small pulmonary nodules identified on CT scan are not apparent radiographically. The possibility of a small pericardial effusion would be difficult to exclude.  There multifocal degenerative changes in the spine and about the shoulders. No obvious lytic or sclerotic lesion is detected. No compression fracture is detected.     IMPRESSION:    1. Right paratracheal/ right apical opacity likely corresponds to a mediastinal mass seen on the ___ chest CT. This extended posteriorly on the previous CT scan. If the patient's symptoms are in the upper right paramedian back, then this might account for the symptoms. 2. Opacities at the left lung apex are stable and likely correspond to a site of prior radiofrequency ablation. 3. No CHF, new infiltrate, effusion, or pneumothorax is detected. Minimal bibasilar atelectasis noted.

column5: HISTORY:  End-stage renal disease on HD.  Plan for OR for AVF revision.    COMPARISON:  None available.  TECHNIQUE:  PA and lateral chest radiographs.    FINDINGS:  A double-lumen dialysis catheter terminates in the low SVC/proximal right atrium.  There is calcification of the aortic knob.  There is mild tortuosity of the descending aorta.  The  heart is mildly enlarged. There is a suggestion of a thin curvilinear myocardial calcification which if real could represent post infarction left ventricular aneurysm. There is however no other evidence of cardiac failure, no pulmonary edema or pleural effusion. An 8 mm round density is seen in the lingula, likely a calcified pulmonary nodule. There is no focal consolidation concerning for pneumonia.     IMPRESSION:  Suggestion of a thin curvilinear myocardial calcification,  if real could represent post infarction left ventricular aneurysm. No other evidence of cardiac failure. Further evaluation can be performed with an ECHO.

There is a 5-mm nodular opacity projecting over the right lower lung, not visualized on the lateral view, and may reflect presence of a small pulmonary nodule or sclerotic focus in the osseous structures. Unchanged bronchiectasis and post radiation changes at the bases.  No new opacity to suggest pneumonia. 3.  Unchanged osseous metastases in T8, T9, and the left sixth rib.

column5: EXAM:  Chest frontal and lateral views.  CLINICAL INFORMATION:  ___ male with history of coronary artery disease, presenting with chest pain.  ___.  FINDINGS:  Frontal and lateral views of the chest were obtained.  The lungs are hyperinflated, suggesting chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Right base opacity is seen which could relate to underlying edema although consolidation is not excluded.  Projecting over the left lung apex, there is a 0.7 cm nodular opacity (also projecting over the mid left clavicle), which while could represent prominent vessel, an underlying pulmonary nodule cannot be excluded. Suggest AP lordotic view for further evaluation and if the finding persists, consider non-urgent CT.  IMPRESSION:  Mild interstitial edema, improved.  Right base opacity could relate to underlying edema although consolidation not excluded.  Blunted left costophrenic angle, may be due to trace effusion or pleural thickening.  0.7 cm nodular opacity projecting over left lung apex, which while could represent prominent vessel, an underlying pulmonary nodule cannot be excluded. Suggest AP lordotic view for further evaluation and if the finding persists, consider non-urgent CT.

column5: PA AND LATERAL CHEST, ___ AT 1738 HOURS.  HISTORY:  Confusion.  COMPARISON:  Multiple priors, the most recent dated ___.  FINDINGS:  A dual-chamber pacemaker AICD and stigmata of prior CABG are all stable relative to prior exams.  Similarly, there is relatively stable blunting of both costophrenic angles and thickening particularly at the right as noted on prior exams.  There is worsening volume loss at the right lung base with bronchovascular crowding.  A distinct nodular opacity is now seen in the right perihilar region projecting over the right posterior sixth rib.  This was not present on prior exams.  Degenerative changes are noted throughout the thoracic spine.  No displaced rib fractures are evident.  No pneumothorax is seen.  Deformity of the left clavicle is presumed due to remote healed trauma.  IMPRESSION:  Relatively stable chest x-ray exam with the exception of a now much more apparent right pulmonary nodular opacity as detailed above.  Given the short interval since the prior study, there is of unclear clinical significance.  However, if indicated, consider chest CT to exclude underlying pulmonary nodule.

column5: INDICATION:  Patient is a ___ male with pulseless left lower extremity.  Preoperative film.  EXAMINATION:  Single frontal chest radiograph.  COMPARISONS:  Radiographs from ___ and FDG-PET from ___.  FINDINGS:  Since the prior examination, there has been significant progression of known primary lung neoplasm, compatible with known clinical metastatic status.  There is relative asymmetry with loss of volume involving the left hemithorax. There are areas of irregular pleural thickening circumferentially involving the entire left hemithorax.  In addition, there is extensive alveolar airspace consolidation noted within the left hemithorax.  The right hemithorax is hyperinflated and well aerated with no focal consolidations, though with known pulmonary nodules and small effusion as better appreciated on the concurrent CT.  Cardiomediastinal contours are obscured by overlying opacification.  Pulmonary vascularity is normal.  There is a S-shaped scoliosis of the spine.  IMPRESSION:  Volume loss involving the left hemithorax with lobulated circumferential pleural contour and alveolar airspace opacification compatible with extensive metastatic disease.  Right-sided pulmonary nodules and pleural effusion is more fully appreciated on concurrent CT examination.

column5: PA AND LATERAL CHEST, ___ AT 12:50 P.M.  HISTORY:  Three to four hours of right lower extremity weakness overnight since resolved.  COMPARISON:  None.  FINDINGS:  The lungs are hyperexpanded likely due to underlying obstructive lung disease.  No consolidation or edema is evident.  There is a subtle nodular density projecting along the inferior margin of the anterior right fourth rib.  There may be a similar structure along the same horizontal line project in the left chest which would then most likely render this nipple shadow.  Otherwise, no definite pulmonary nodule or mass seen.  There is tortuosity of the thoracic aorta with dense calcified plaque at the arch.  The cardiac silhouette is top normal for size.  No effusion or pneumothorax is seen.  The osseous structures are unremarkable.  IMPRESSION:  No acute process.  There is suggestion of underlying obstructive lung disease.  Nodular densities likely correspond to nipples.  Consider nipple markers with subsequent chest x-ray imaging.  Given high risk, consider chest CT on a nonurgent basis to assess for underlying pulmonary nodule or mass.
